title: The incredible stories of heroism in Prince Harry Heart of Invictus
body_text:
The incredible stories of heroism in Prince Harry's Heart of Invictus: From the Ukrainian medic held captive by Putin's forces to the US Navy hero who battles through daily pain
Prince Harry's new Netflix documentary showcases incredible stories of heroism from veterans who competed in his Invictus Games.
The five-part Heart of Invictus documentary, which launched this morning, follows a group of former military servicemen and women on their road to the paralympic-style sporting competition Invictus.
The series details the sacrifices that veterans and their families make while serving their country, including those an Ukrainian medic who was held captive by Putin's forces, a US Navy hero who battles through daily pain and a soldier who lost both his legs in an IED explosion.
It also highlights the story of a British army captain who played an intricate role in Harry's creation of the Invictus Games. The Duke of Sussex set up the sporting competition in 2014 for injured and sick military personnel and veterans.
Heart of Invictus has been released in the run-up to next month's Invictus Games which begins in Dusseldorf on September 9, with Harry set to travel to Germany for the start of the tournament, and his wife Meghan joining later.
MailOnline takes a look at some of the stories of heroism showcased in the new documentary...
Former army captain David Wiseman (pictured next to Harry) played a big part in the inaugural Invictus Games in London in 2014. Mr Wiseman had suffered a gun shot to the chest while serving in Afghanistan, which led the end of his military career
Paramedic Yuliia 'Taira' Paievska (pictured) was training for the tournament when she was captured and held prisoner by Russian troops last year. She was tortured for three months and eventually released in the wake of global publicity at The Hague games about her situation
Tom Folwell, (pictured) a former Army plant operator mechanic, served two tours in Iraq and half a tour in Afghanistan before he lost both his legs in an IED explosion
DAVID WISEMAN
Former army captain David Wiseman played a big part in the inaugural Invictus Games in London in 2014.
Mr Wiseman had suffered a gun shot to the chest while serving in Afghanistan, which led the end of his military career.
'After I was shot I was in fairly s**t state,' he told the documentary. 'The round travelled the length of my torso, hit my ribs at the back, hit my ribs at the front, rattled around a little bit like a pinball before coming to rest in my right lung.
'And I stopped breathing. And I stopped breathing a couple of times.
'When I was a soldier that meant the world to me and then, once I was wounded, well, how do you define yourself then?'
Alongside Harry, Mr Wiseman was a 'driving force of the Invictus movement'. The veteran previously told the BBC that he realised sport was the vehicle that could help struggling former servicemen find their purpose while he was climbing some of the highest mountains in the world.
Alongside Harry, Mr Wiseman was a 'driving force of the Invictus movement'. He was sitting with the Duke at the 2013 Warrior Games in Colorado when Harry brought up the idea. Harry and Mr Wiseman are pictured together during a hike
He was sitting with the Duke at the 2013 Warrior Games in Colorado when Harry brought up the idea.
'He said: 'These Games are fantastic, but we're going to take it back to the UK and I want it in the Olympic Stadium and on the BBC, I want it massive and international,' Mr Wiseman told the broadcaster. 'We were just like, 'Oh my goodness, let's see what we can do.''
Mr Wiseman helped Harry develop the competition and has also competed in it over the years.
YULIA PAIEVSKA
The series also charts the story of the Ukrainian team preparing for the competition in The Hague in 2022 against the backdrop of the Russian invasion.
It tells the story of paramedic Yuliia 'Taira' Paievska who was training for the tournament when she was captured and held prisoner by Russian troops last year.
She was tortured for three months and eventually released in the wake of global publicity at The Hague games about her situation.
A week after her release, Ms Paievska received a call from Prince Harry which she claimed 'inspired me to continue to fight'.
'He said that he supports Ukraine and all of us,' she previously told The Telegraph, adding: 'The Invictus Games family always takes care of its members.'
Yuliia Paievska (pictured) received a call from Prince Harry after her release, which she claimed 'inspired me to continue to fight'. She said she was 'very grateful' to Harry because it was after the Invictus Games that Russian troops stopped 'interrogating and torturing me'
Ms Paievska said she first heard about the Invictus Games while she was in hospital after on of her surgeries. She is pictured in February 2021 at an open training session for the games
Ms Paievska also said she was 'very grateful' to Harry because it was after the Invictus Games that Russian troops stopped 'interrogating and torturing me'.
She added: 'I think that spreading the word to the whole world influenced their decision to trade me in a prisoner exchange.'
Ms Paievska began working on the Ukrainian frontline in 2014. She was later injured during an evacuation operation.
'Seven years on the front, I have titanium joints in my legs, my backbone suffers, and I've been having these traumas for a long time,' she told the Netflix documentary, adding that test results revealed she had suffered two heart attacks. Her medical condition forced her reconsider her role as a paramedic.
She said she first heard about the Invictus Games while she was in hospital after on of her surgeries.
TOM FOLWELL
Tom Folwell, a former Army plant operator mechanic, served two tours in Iraq and half a tour in Afghanistan before he lost both his legs in an IED explosion.
'I lost both my legs. Injuries to my back. The blast went into my forearm. My wrist got pins in,' he told the documentary.
Mr Folwell was in hospital for two months before he underwent over two years of rehabilitation with his prosthetics.
'After I got blown up, I just...drinking a lot, going out a lot. Not in the best space,' he recalled. Mr Folwell said his wife told him 'something needs to change'.
He was made captain of both the GB wheelchair rugby and basketball team, as well as the sitting volleyball team, at last year's Invictus Games.
He said he 'didn't have a clue why anyone would consider me' when the coach made him captain.
Tom Folwell (pictured) was made captain of both the GB wheelchair rugby and basketball team, as well as the sitting volleyball team, at last year's Invictus Games. He turned his life around after he lost both his legs and started 'drinking a lot, going out a lot'
'I've never been in a leadership role in my life, for anything,' he said. 'Clearly someone sees something in me, just not me.'
The veteran also inspired England football manager Gareth Southgate last year when they met ahead of the World Cup.
Mr Folwell, in November 2022, told The Lincolnite that he thought Mr Southgate would 'understand how soldiers feel when they suffer life changing injuries with all his football experience'.
The football manager said at the time that both military members and footballers 'can find their careers cut short due to injury'.
He told the newspaper: 'The inability to function or perform in the same way after injury can often cause significant mental challenges, loss of identity and impact their prospects.'
Mr Folwell, addressing the end of his military career in the Netflix series, said he treats it like a 'past life'. He added: 'My new life [has] started, nothing to do with the military anymore.'
GABE GEORGE
Gabe George, a retired Navy Corpsman, lost his right arm after it was paralysed in a motorcycle accident in 2008.
A driver made a U-turn at a light without seeing Mr George and the pair collided, he told the documentary, adding that he woke up three weeks later.
'I made a pact with my arm. I told it, 'If you don't get better, I'll cut you off,'' he shared. His arm was amputated about 12 years after the accident.
Mr George said he has been in pain 'every day' since. He moves around a lot because it 'keeps my mind off' of the pain and 'keeps my body moving'.
It took about 12 years before his arm was amputated, he shared, noting how 'I made a pact with my arm. I told it, 'If you don't get better, I'll cut you off.''
Gabe George, (pictured) a retired Navy Corpsman, lost his right arm after it was paralysed in a motorcycle accident in 2008. A driver made a U-turn at a light without seeing Mr George and the pair collided, he told the documentary, adding that he woke up three weeks later
Mr George, who went of a scuba dive in Hawaii with Prince Harry last November, says he now considers the Duke to be 'like a brother'. He said that as a service member Harry 'was able to understand and to relate' to what he had been through. The pair are pictured together during the Invictus Games last year
Mr George (pictured) competed for Team USA at the Invictus Games last year in the Hague. He made his mark in archery, swimming and rowing
Mr George competed for Team USA at the Invictus Games last year in the Hague. He made his mark in archery, swimming and rowing.
The serviceman, who went of a scuba dive in Hawaii with Harry last November, says he now considers the Duke to be 'like a brother'.
He told People Magazine how the pair instantly clicked at the Games, alleging that it may be due to the 'military connection that we have'. He added that Harry 'was able to understand and to relate' to what he had been through.
Mr George said the Invictus Games has 'added a lot of fuel to my life' and inspired him to help train others in adaptive sports.
NA HYEONGYOON
South Korean Army veteran Na Hyeongyoon had both hands amputated after being electrocuted in an incident he has no memory of.
He told the documentary how the doctors informed him it would 'be better' to amputate.
'My dream was to become either a soldier or a policeman in order to protect the country,' he said. However, that dream had to change after he lost his hands.
Mr Hyeongyoon now says that meeting his wife was the best thing to ever happen to him, but the second best was 'starting sports'.
He explained that in his homeland having a disability is considered to be 'wrong' and people tend to 'hide themselves away'.
South Korean Army veteran Na Hyeongyoon (pictured) had both hands amputated after being electrocuted in an incident he has no memory of. He told the documentary how the doctors informed him it would 'be better' to amputate
Mr Hyeongyoon (pictured) used his prosthetic hands to become an accomplished cyclist. He said that his cycling coaches are 'surprised' when they watch his team compete, sharing how they often question: 'How can disabled people be this good?'
But instead of hiding, he used his prosthetic hands to become an accomplished cyclist.
He said that his cycling coaches are 'surprised' when they watch his team compete, sharing how they often question: 'How can disabled people be this good?'
'I don't think society has changed much yet, but it needs to change now,' Mr Hyeongyoon said, adding: 'Starting with me.
'I'm participating in these games and I want everyone to watch us, not only with pity, but to see all the things less-abled bodies can do. I hope that people will give us a fighting spirit!'
South Korea competed in the Games for the first time in 2022.
KASPAR HOLM HENRIKSEN
Kaspar Holm Henriksen is currently suffering with acute PTSD, a 'devastating hidden injury'. Team Denmark is solely comprised of members living with PTSD.
Mr Henriksen said he was part of the first Danish team to go to Iraq and 'didn't know what to expect' when he was deployed.
He told the Heart of Invictus series how the PTSD began following an incident in the streets of Al-Qurnah, where he and his team 'saw fierce combat'.
He remembers grabbing his ammunition and running towards another soldier straight across a field.
'I could hear the shots. They were very close,' he recalled. 'It started the PTSD. The times when they bombed our camp have also left their marks.'
Kaspar Holm Henriksen (pictured) is currently suffering with acute PTSD, a 'devastating hidden injury'. Team Denmark is solely comprised of members living with PTSD
He said he became a soldier because 'I wanted to help other people, and I thought I was going to make a difference in the world'.
Mr Henriksen said that after he returned from Iraq, it was 'very difficult for me to connect with people.' He said finding the community within the Invictus Games has been 'very important for me'.
He hopes competing together will help both him and team find themselves again.
Like Mr Henriksen, the Duke of Sussex said that returning from his tour in Afghanistan triggered an emotional 'unravelling'. He told the docuseries that the 'biggest struggle for me was that no one around me could really help'.
He said he wants the Invictus Games to offer a 'support structure' or 'network' to veterans, which he claims he didn't have himself.
